topic.title: Gitweb on ZeroNet?
topic.body:
Anybody managed to get gitweb to work on ZeroNet yet? I've seen [0git](http://127.0.0.1:43110/0git.bit/), but a lot of the repos are in clearnet. On top of that, there doesn't seem to be a way to clone most of the ZeroNet repos...

Having a place to host massively distributed code repositories is key to making decentralization self-sufficient.

1_1GgNo3CmxPd7n2pMSF3uyqf1XHvgtTUqCe.body:
arch is the way to go, once you've got the basics down from messing w/ other linux distros.
but if you're concerned about proprietary software, you might want to try gentoo instead. it's mostly the same as arch, but it's FOSS all the way down

> [jmsebastian](#comment_2_1Gu13rN1pkfocLRtoHdTyChZTq1yNHgwcB): Gaming on Linux is definitely better than it used to, no doubt about it. Sadly, the sheer amount of games available for Windows means it will be the predominant PC gaming platform for a long, long time. Macs have become a non-platform for games, which is partly why I think Linux has made some headway. That and developer tools have made compiling for Linux or multiple platforms a lot easier than it used to be. Were I not into games, I would have given up on Windows a long time ago.

With where windows seems to be heading, I think Linux is the future for games. Wine will (eventually) pick up the titles that get left unported.

> [jmsebastian](#comment_3_1Gu13rN1pkfocLRtoHdTyChZTq1yNHgwcB): We will have to see. I think Microsoft has made a lot of effort to keep developers, at least large developers, interested in making games for Windows. Steam's dominance of the marketplace, while available for multiple platforms, is still very heavily focused on Windows. [...]

True, but as more and more games get released for Linux, the friction related to those releases starts to lessen. I think Linux is at the slow end of an exponential growth curve, and we'll see parity in 15 yrs or so. I'm, of course, probably wrong, since I also had high hopes for SteamOS, which kinda flopped.

As for Wine, it's already possible to play a few modern windows-only games on Linux (Overwatch, for example), and as development continues it'll only support more and more titles.

> [kaffie](#comment_338_1NWh3WAty57FH8at1WtrZigMrdhrDkuPzh): Perhaps take a look at git over zeronet? I'm using it to host Kaffiene's git repo. Works well.

This is a bit more involved than what I'd like, though it is very cool. Ideally, I think it'd be good to have something as user-friendly as GitHub, but backed by zeronet, using optional files to house tarred/compressed headless git repos.

This will definitely work for now, though. Thanks!

> [kaffie](#comment_339_1NWh3WAty57FH8at1WtrZigMrdhrDkuPzh): The big question is the technical side of things. You have to make sure that git will actually push to such a site. [...]

After looking at the source of `git-remote-zeronet`, it looks like it just translates a zeronet address to the local file path of that site, so pushing would work exactly the same as pushing to a local repo specified by a file path. The only special bit (pushing to peers) is done transparently by the handler at line 140.

The site itself is just an index.html, content.json and .git folder. Nothing special about how it's done.

> [kaffie](#comment_339_1NWh3WAty57FH8at1WtrZigMrdhrDkuPzh): [...] One way could be to make a site like 0git, but as a merger site (kinda like zerome) and then have git repos act as 'hubs' that you can download and look through.[...]

Merger sites were not a thing I had considered; they'd definitely work better here than optional files. The issue then becomes maintaining a list of merger sites, and generating previews for them. The main reason I wanted optional files was so a user can look at a repo without needing to download it. I think it should be possible to have the merger sites have a file list, short description, and README file as non-optional files, and the rest of the repo as optional. The user could click `Make clonable` or something to download all the optional bits of the repo.

The only other thing I'd like to see is private repos, which would have to somehow be readable to only a subset of users.

> [kaffie](#comment_339_1NWh3WAty57FH8at1WtrZigMrdhrDkuPzh): [...] build some sort of github frontend [...]

I must admit that I am completely incompetent when it comes to UIs. I'd be happy to start work on the backend bits (merge site template, merge site listing, etc) but until someone volunteers to help with UI work, I can't get too far with this.

I will get started on this though, but I'll use a clearnet host (probably GitHub) till it's done enough to host itself reliably.

I've started a Github org for anyone who wants to hop in during the design phase: https://github.com/0GH

It's sparse at the moment, but I'm basing a lot of the docs off of IPFS's excellent collection, so it'll grow pretty quickly.

Send me a message on zeromail if you want to join the org and help out. You'll need a modern (rsa4096/ed25519) GPG key to sign your commits. Ideally, it should be attached to your Github account so each commit can be verified.

My zeromail is skwerlman@Mail.ZeroNetwork.bit.

> [kmueller](#comment_74_1PvReUtzc5s92BWTUDnxvmVGepNcyA2otB): If the 80% are BS, please present another percentage based on data.

My point was not to provide you with new magic numbers to twist to your advantage, but rather to encourage you to do your own research instead of just throwing 80% out there as if it were the unassailable truth. However, since you've asked, and I'm a nice person, here you go:

Since the US has decided that it doesn't need to care about the mental health of its homeless people, there is very little in the way of concrete stats. However, Canada has slightly better reporting on the issue, so I'll use their numbers. Note that these numbers are self-reported, and were only gathered in Ontario. Note also that substance abuse (incl alcoholism) is included as a mental disorder.

Accorging to [this study](http://rspace.uwaterloo.ca/xmlui/bitstream/handle/20.500.11895/261/2015%20Mental%20Illness%20%26%20Homelessness.pdf?sequence=1&isAllowed=y) (WARN: clearnet) 34% of homeless people have suffered from a mental illness at some point in their lives. This __does not__ mean that they had one at the time of the study, so the percentage of homeless people who _currently_ have a mental disorder (including addiction) is even lower. As mentioned in the study, previous studies had found that as many as 66% of homeless people had mental disorders, but even this high-ball estimate is lower than your made-up right-wing fantasy 80% number.

Additionally, its worth pointing out that homeless people are in fact people, even if they suffer from mental health or addiction issues.

Persons in families means people who are homeless, but still live with their (also homeless) family.

https://www.hudexchange.info/resources/documents/2016-AHAR-Part-1.pdf (WARN: clearnet)
Note that the numbers here are for a single night in January, not for the whole year. The number of people who experience homelessness over the course of the entire year is somewhere between 2 and 5 million people.

Additionally, being sheltered and having a home are two very different things. A person who is sheltered on one night might not be the next, while someone who has a home can reasonably expect to still have it the next day.

1_15Rn4kLyQf7tKstyyW3W9DV9VtCMNc4X9P.body:
it depends on the sites you browse, and whether you decide to share optional content for those sites

each site is stored locally on your disk, so, naturally, the more sites you browse, the more space gets used.

additionally, some sites have optional media (like pictures on zerome) which isn't saved until you decide to view it. Each optional file also increases the amount of space used.

As an example, after ~2 months of light-medium browsing, my zeronet data folder is using 1.7 GB to store 94 sites, including merge sites, although the growth of those numbers is much slower now than it was a month ago.
